pages.text:
Title: Joseph Banks and the British Museum. The World of Collecting, 1770-1830

Abstract: Sir Joseph Banks, as trustee of the British Museum for forty-two years, oversaw much of the work of members of its staff (a relationship described as ‘supervisory involvement’ by the author of this book). Today, both of these modalities would be frowned on: trustees of national museums are now rarely allowed to serve for more than eight years, while board and executive are expected to adhere to clearly defined and separate roles. Yet it is clear that Banks's contribution to the Museum was immense, and that in a variety of fields, mainly natural history and ethnography, but others as well, he laid the basis for the richness of many of the collections. Indeed, had his activities been ruled by current guidelines, it is no exaggeration to say that both the British Museum and the Natural History Museum would now be lesser institutions. Banks was born into a wealthy landowning family...
